awd_titl_txt: Molecular basis of tunable iridescence and excellent proton conductance of the reflectin assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
Reflectins are a family of largely-disordered proteins in cephalopods that form tunable nano-assemlies to enable instantaneous change of their body color. In vitro these assemblies exhibit superb protonic conductance, comparable to the-state-of-the-art artificial materials. This project will elucidate the molecular mechanism underpinning the tunable coloration and superb protonic conductivity of reflectins. This knowledge will enable rational design of bio-compatible artificial materials based on reflectins with programmable optical and electrical properties. Multiple undergraduates and one graduate will be trained. The PI will exploit the fascinating nature of the protein in his outreach activities for local K-12 schools to promote STEM and to inspire next general scientists and engineers.


Several conserved amino acid sequences were found in homologous reflectins, recapitulating the properties of the full-length proteins. The intriguing optical and electrical properties were attributed to the ordered hierarchical structures and accompanied hydrogen bonding network in assemblies. However, the strong disorder of subunit proteins prohibits characterization at high resolution by techniques such as cryoEM or X-ray diffraction. This project will apply solid state NMR (ssNMR), the ideal technique for noncrystalline sample, to determine the atomic structural model of the assembly formed by one of the conserved fragments called (ref2C)4. This knowledge will resolve the paradox: how largely disordered subunit proteins assemble into ordered Bragg reflectors at light wavelength scale to modulate optical properties. Further ssNMR experiments will be performed to probe proton diffusion in the assembly, which will dissect the molecular motif at a residue-specific resolution responsible for the outstanding protonic conductivity.

This proposal is co-funded by Division of Materials Research (MPS/DMR), Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems (ENG/CBET) and Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences (BIO/MCB).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we studied the structure and function correlation of the self-assembly formed by polypeptide (ref2C)4 derived from the conserved sequence of E. scolopes reflectin in by solid state NMR (ssNMR). Specifically, the following findings are obtained in the supported research period
Intellectual merit: 1. Via collaboration, we find the assembly exhibits excellent proton conductivity over long distance (0.4 mS/cm over ~ 1 mm), which suggests its potential as bioelectronic materials.
2. Our ssNMR characterization shows that the assembly comprises three short alpha helices spanned by residue R3-D6, Y14-Y18, M21-T24, with the rest of the peptide adopting random coil conformation.
3. Our ssNMR characterization shows that the assembly is stabilized by the cation-pi interaction between various Tyr and Arg residues in the peptide.
4. The NMR relaxation measurements find strong proton exchange between water with Tyr and Arg residues in the assembly, decreasing with increasing temperature. This observation is consistent with the increasing proton conductivity over temperature that our collaboration identified , which suggests that the high proton conductitivy of the assembly arises from the proton exchange between side-chain of Tyr and Arg with water.
Broad impacts: Signal assignment in congested ssNMR spectra is a known bottleneck that impedes the application of ssNMR, while the structure information at a site-specific level can only be resolved after the signal can be assigned. In this work, we face broad NMR resonance lines (1.5-3 in the assembly formed by polypeptide (ref2C)4 exhibits. We invented an auto-assignment program called "automatic-sequential assignment program" (ASAP). It partially overcomes some of the technical challenges to assign signals in congested multidimensional ssNMR spectra. The work describing ASAP program was published and the source code was shared with the public over GitHub. It significantly reduces the manual work required to accurately assign signals in congested ssNMR spectra to expedite the structure determination by ssNMR. 
2. Over the suppored period, one PhD, multiple undergraduate and high school students were trained from under-represented group (African American).


Last Modified: 07/10/2024
Modified by: Bo Chen

Images (1 of )
  • The proton exchange was measured by NMR relaxation experiments over 278 to 303 K, decreasing with increasing temperatures

    The proton exchange rate between Tyr 158 ppm site with water chain as a function of temperature.
  • The (ref2C)4 molecule comprises three short alpha helices connected by random coils, determined by ssNMR.
    Unpublished results, from Bo Chen's NMR group
    Copyrighted
    Bo Chen
    Secondary structure composition of the self-assembly formed by polypeptide (ref2C)4
